page.title: 02HISTORY OF BALDERTON
page.content: Balderton village was of Saxon creation. The 'ton' or farm of one Balder, named after the god of beauty. By the 13th. century the manor had developed into a prosperous area with a church, dovecote, windmill and hall. The village, by 1550, consisted of a manor, grange, parsonage and half timbered cottages of mud and plaster. Sheep rearing was declining but the culture of grapes for wine continued. In addition to farming the local industries of rope and brick making and quarrying were established. In 1664, during the Civil War, Balderton found itself billeted by Parliamentary troops; whilst Newark remained a Royalist stronghold. In 1786 the area was enclosed by an Act of Parliament.
